chapter.title: Sojourners
chapter.subtitle: גרם - Gerim
chapter.para:
The ger is a sojourner. A ger can be bnei Yisrael or not.
"I am a stranger and a sojourner with you: give me a possession of a buryingplace with you, that I may bury my dead out of my sight." - Genesis 23:4 KJV The ger without any other qualifier is almost always referring to ger tzedek in halachah.
Hilchot Assurot Machalot 11:8

The ger is anyone who attaches themselves to Godliness in some way and is not an idol-worshipper. This attachment could be by Torah, by interacting and clinging to bnei Yisrael, or by contemplating on the true nature of haShem and his wisdom. The ger is a sojourner. He may or may not have the greatest of intentions.

Ger is often seen translated into English as the stranger. In Torah, he is the stranger in the gate, the person that attaches himself to bnei Yisrael. However, this is not an accurate translation. Stranger in Hebrew is actually the zer. Ger is more accurately translated as sojourner.

sect1.title: Halacha
sect1.para: In Torah shebikhtav, ger usually refers to a ger toshav. In Torah shebe'alpeh, ger usually refers a ger tzedek.

sect1.title: Responsa
sect1.para: Statement: The Ger Toshav doesn't exist today
Statement: A ger toshav is still a goy

Response: Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8:"when we say plainly 'goy', we mean an idolator".Is Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8 a true statement Jacob?The response you've made to my argument is an ad hominem(personal attack) and is not a valid argument; they are obfuscations. You also have yet to disprove any of the other arguments I've said. Concerning the Issurei Biah 14:7:You say that the ger toshav is a goy even after he swears off idolatry.Using that logic, when Issurei Biah 13:3 says a ger tzedek is a goy as well, you're still able to call him a goy:"When a goy desires to enter into the covenant..."However, a ger tzedek is no longer a goy, lest you say all converts cannot keep shabbat, study Torah, etc. per Hilchot Melachim 10:9 "A goy cannot study Torah...". Following the rule in set theory, a subset follows all the attributes of its superset, so when you call a ger a subset of goy, this cannot be the case.

For instance:set all integers: {1,2,3,4,5,6,..}set even integers: {2,4,6,...}Set "even integers" being a subset of "all integers", and if "all integers" turn pink then "even integers" would turn pink due to inheritance by set theory. Therefore, ger toshav is not a subset of goy. Rather, a ger toshav(a non-idolator) is no longer a goy(idolator). They are not goy(idolator). They are ger(non-idolator).The only way(and I would agree with you) that gerim are subsets, is in the Torah definition of goy, such as bnei Yisrael being a goy kodesh(a holy nation). However, we're not talking in the written Torah term, but rather in the halachic term, as defined by the Rambam, Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8:"when we say plainly 'goy', we mean an idolator". Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8 is true statement. If it is true, the you should read Issurei Biah 14:7 as:"Who is a ger toshav? This is an idolator which accepts upon himself to not serve idolatry, [along] with the other commandments commanded to the children of Noach"This also explains why rabbis refer to ger toshav as "half-converts"(as in Avodah Berurah, Avodah Zarah 64b). They were once idol-worshippers, who accepted not to be.You have not shown my argument to be invalid or false. Standing alone and apart from the rest of Mishneh Torah, your argument for Issurei Biah is valid(which would assume the Torah definition of goy), but coupled with the axiom of Maachalot Assurot 11:8(which assumes the halachic Rambam definition of goy), your argument is not valid.
